page.title: 02Local History-Broughton/Holt
page.content: Broughton Gifford derives its name from the saxon Broctun-a farm by a brook and from the family name of John Gifford, who purchased it in 1269 from Walter de Dunstanville. Holts name derives from hillwood perhaps due to the large oakwood which once spread from Broughton and Chalfield towards Holt. Chalfield comes from cold or chilly field. The area was part of the land granted to Ethelred in 1001 AD. to the monastery of Shaftesbury so that "the nuns might have a safe retreat from the ravages of the Danes". TRADITION Broughton Common, which covers 28 acres, is traditionally known as Ganderland and those living around it as Ganders because at one time most families kept geese. Many houses still have goose-holes in the garden wall.
